oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Evaluation of the surface area of P3 in dairy calves following changes in management systems
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gard, J. A.
Wilhite, D. R.
Taylor, D. C.
Rodning, S. P.
Edmondson, M.
Sanders, K.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: lameness
beef cattle
dairy cattle
economic
primiparous
multiparous
feet
hooves
rocky terrain
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lameness negatively affects the well-being and economic productivity of beef and dairy cattle. It has been reported that the prevalence of lameness in dairy herds is nearly 20% for primiparous cows and almost 50% for multiparous cows. Hence, evaluation, development, and implementation of better management protocols are necessary to produce replacements which have healthy functional feet able to withstand the rigors of the industry. The focus of this study was to evaluate whether the honey structures in calves' feet will remodel and develop when exposed to rocky terrain.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2012; 232
